facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1869 of 1968 was filed under section 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1869 of 1968. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1968 of the Rajasthan High Court in Election Petition No. 16 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated August 12, 1968 of Rajasthan High Court in Election Petition No. 16 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1968 of the Rajasthan High Court in Election Petition No. 16 of 1967.

facts.text: Mrs. Kanta Kathuria stood as candidate for election to Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from Kolayat Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Kathuria is an advocate practicing at Bikaner. She companytested the above election held on February 18, 1967 against seven other candidates.

facts.text: Election held on February 18, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: She companytested the above election held on February 18, 1967 against seven other candidates. She was declared elected on February 22, 1967.

facts.text: Mrs. Kanta Kathuria declared elected on February 22, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: She was declared elected on February 22, 1967. One of the defeated candidates filed the election petition, from which this appeal arises, questioning her election on several grounds.

facts.text: One defeated candidate filed election petition questioning her election.

anchor.surface_text: One of the defeated candidates filed the election petition, from which this appeal arises, questioning her election on several grounds. We are companycerned only with one of them, namely, that on the date of her numberination and election she was disqualified

facts.text: Mrs. Kathuria held office of Special Government Pleader on date of nomination and election, claimed to disqualify her under Article 191.

anchor.surface_text: namely, that on the date of her numberination and election she was disqualified to be chosen to fill the seat as she held the office of Special Government Pleader, which was an office of profit under the Government of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Mrs. Kathuria appointed as Special Government Pleader on June 26, 1965 by Government of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Kathuria was appointed by the Government of Rajasthan as Special Government Pleader to companyduct arbitration cases between the Government and Modern Construction Company arising out of the companystruction of Rana Pratap Sagar Dam and Jawahar Sagar Dam. The order was passed on June 26, 1965  Ex. 1 .

facts.text: Appointment to conduct arbitration cases between Government and Modern Construction Company re Rana Pratap Sagar Dam and Jawahar Sagar Dam.

anchor.surface_text: The order reads ORDER Sub Construction of R.P.S. Main Dam-Contract of M s. M.C.C.  Pvt.  Ltd., Arbitration in disputes arising out of. In pursuance of Rule 8  b  of Order XXVII of the First Schedule to the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 read with clause  7  of Section 2 of the Code, the Governor is pleased to appoint Smt. Kanta Kathuria

facts.text: Remuneration fixed at Rs. 150 per day for hearing, Rs. 75 per day for travel/adjourned/preparation.

anchor.surface_text: By subsequent orders, which we do number companysider necessary to quote here, her remuneration was fixed at Rs. 1501- per day for each date of hearing, Rs. 75/- per day for days of travel and dates on which the case was adjourned, and days spent on preparation of the case.

facts.text: Mrs. Kathuria appeared from March 27, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Kathuria began appearing in the case from March 27, 1965.

facts.text: Paid Rs. 26,325 for work from March 27, 1965 to November 28, 1966; Rs. 900 from February 26, 1967 to March 2, 1967. Admitted fact.

anchor.surface_text: It is an admitted fact that she was paid for work between that date and November 28, 1966 a sum of Rs. 26,325/- and again from February 26, 1967 to March 2, 1967 a sum of Rs. 900/- and that the arbitration proceedings were companytinuing on the date of the filing of the election petition.

facts.text: Arbitration proceedings continuing on date of filing election petition.

anchor.surface_text: and that the arbitration proceedings were companytinuing on the date of the filing of the election petition. Therefore for over two years she was employed as Special Government Pleader

facts.text: High Court held Mrs. Kathuria disqualified.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the High Court held that Mrs. Kathuria was disqualified.

facts.text: Governor of Rajasthan issued Ordinance 3/68 on December 24, 1968 removing disqualification retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: Before this appeal came on for hearing before us, the Governor of Rajasthan by Ordinance 3/68  December 24, 1968  removed the disqualification retrospectively. The Ordinance was followed by Act V of 1968  April 4, 1969 .

facts.text: Rajasthan Act V of 1969 assented April 4, 1969, declares Special Government Pleader office does not disqualify retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance was followed by Act V of 1968  April 4, 1969 . The operative portions of the Act which are the same as of the Ordinance read Prevention of disqualification of membership of the State Legislative Assembly- It is hereby declared that numbere of the following offices...

facts.text: Election petition filed by Shri Manik Chand Surana, defeated candidate.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of an election petition filed under section 80 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, hereinafter referred to as the 1951 Act, by Shri Manik Chand Surana, a defeated candidate, challenging the election of Smt. Kanta Kathuria, before the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant secured 11926 votes, respondent 8311.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was declared duly elected by the Returning officer on, February 22, 1967, the appellant having secured 11926 and the respondent having secured 8311 votes.

facts.text: Mrs. Kathuria began appearing March 27, 1965 to Nov 28, 1966, not from Nov29,1966-Feb25,1967, then from Feb26,1967.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appeared from March 27, 1965 to November 28, 1966, but she did number appear from Nov. 29, 1966 to Feb. 25, 1967. She again started appearing in the case from February 26, 1967.

facts.text: Office first held by Mr. Maneklal Mathur before Mrs. Kathuria.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that it was first held by Mr. Maneklal Mathur another advocate. It is likely that if Mrs. Kathuria had declined some one else would have been found.

facts.text: Prior to employment, Mrs. Kathuria never paid income-tax over Rs.1200 in a year. Admitted.

anchor.surface_text: It is also admitted by her that prior to this employment, she had never paid income-tax in excess of Rs. 1200/- in any year.

facts.text: High Court allowed election petition on ground of office of profit (Jagat Narayan J.).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court  Jagat Narayan, J.  allowed the election petition on the ground that the appellant held an office of profit within the meaning of Art. 191 of the Constitution on the day on which she filed the numberination paper

facts.text: Appeal filed in Supreme Court on August 20, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment was given on August 12, 1968. An appeal was filed in this Court on August 20, 1968.

facts.text: Shri Murli Manohar Vyas, Government Advocate, appointed to represent in arbitration; wanted assistance.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Murli Manohar Vyas, Government Advocate in the High Court of Rajasthan at Jodhpur was appointed by the Government to represent it in these arbitration proceedings. The Government Advocate wanted one more advocate to assist him.

facts.text: Shri Manak Lal Mathur appointed to assist, but Mrs. Kathuria appointed in his absence on suggestion of Govt Advocate.

anchor.surface_text: On his suggestion, Shri Manak Lal Mathur advocate was appointed to assist the Government Advocate. As there was a possibility that Shri Manak Lal Mathur may number be available... the appellant was, on the suggestion of the Government Advocate, appointed to assist him in the ,absence of Shri Mathur.
Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1968 of the Rajasthan High Court in Election Petition No. 16 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Article 191 of the Constitution, which is relevant in this connection, reads 191 Disqualifications for membership A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State-  a  if he holds any office of profit under the Government of India or the Government of any State specified in the First Schedule, other than an office declared by the Legislature of the State by law number to disqualify its holder

concepts.interpretation: Disqualification if holds office of profit unless declared by state legislature not to disqualify

anchor.surface_text: Section 82 of the Representation of the People Act, 1 of 1951, reads as follows A petitioner shall join as respondents to his petition-  a  where the petitioner, in addition to claiming a ,declaration that the election of all or any of the returned candidates is void, claims a further declaration that be himself or any other- candidate has been duly elected. all the companytesting candidates other than the petitioner and where numbersuch further declaration is claimed, all the returned candidates and  b  any other candidate against whom allegations of any companyrupt practice are made in the petition.

concepts.interpretation: Requires joining candidates from same constituency against whom corrupt practices alleged; other constituencies not required

issues.text: Whether Mrs. Kanta Kathuria was holding an office of profit under the Government of Rajasthan as Special Government Pleader on the date of her nomination and election, disqualifying her under Article 191(1)(a) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: namely, that on the date of her numberination and election she was disqualified to be chosen to fill the seat as she held the office of Special Government Pleader, which was an office of profit under the Government of Rajasthan. Article 191 of the Constitution, which is relevant in this companynection, reads 191 Disqualifications for membership A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State-  a  if he holds any office of profit under the Government of India or the Government of any State specified in the First Schedule, other than an office declared by the Legislature of the State by law number to disqualify its holder Mrs. Kathuria was appointed by the Government of Rajasthan as Special Government Pleader to companyduct arbitration cases between the Government and Modern Construction Company arising out of the companystruction of Rana Pratap Sagar Dam and Jawahar Sagar Dam. The order was passed on June 26, 1965  Ex. 1 . The order reads ORDER Sub Construction of R.P.S. Main Dam-Contract of M s. M.C.C.  Pvt.  Ltd., Arbitration in disputes arising out of. In pursuance of Rule 8  b  of Order XXVII of the First Schedule to the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 read with clause  7  of Section 2 of the Code, the Governor is pleased to appoint Smt. Kanta Kathuria

issues.text: Whether the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly Members (Prevention of Disqualification) Act, 1969 (Act V of 1969) validly removes the disqualification retrospectively under Article 191(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: Before this appeal came on for hearing before us, the Governor of Rajasthan by Ordinance 3/68  December 24, 1968  removed the disqualification retrospectively. The Ordinance was followed by Act V of 1968  April 4, 1969 . The operative portions of the Act which are the same as of the Ordinance read Prevention of disqualification of membership of the State Legislative Assembly- It is hereby declared that numbere of the following offices... The Ordinance and the Act seem to have been passed to nullify the decision in this case. One of the contentions of the answering respondent is that the Legislature of Rajasthan could number remove the disqualification retrospectively since the Constitution contemplates disqualifications existing at certain time in accordance with the law existing at that time.

arguments.claim: Special Government Pleader appointment under CPC Order 27 R8(b) and S2(7) does not create an office, just engagement to conduct case
arguments.court_reasoning: Notification under rule does not create office; mere deeming for purpose of Order 27

arguments.claim: Office must be subsisting, permanent, substantive position independent of holder, filled successively (Rowlatt J test)

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that it was first held by Mr. Maneklal Mathur another advocate. It is likely that if Mrs. Kathuria had declined some one else would have been found.

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature competent to declare retrospectively under Art 191(1)(a); settled practice, no constitutional bar

arguments.claim: State Legislature cannot retrospectively remove disqualification under Art 191 as it contemplates disqualification at time per existing law

anchor.surface_text: One of the contentions of the answering respondent is that the Legislature of Rajasthan could not remove the disqualification retrospectively since the Constitution contemplates disqualifications existing at certain time

arguments.court_reasoning: No express/implied restriction; legislatures can legislate retrospectively; Art 191 authorizes declaration by law

arguments.claim: Act is declaratory/remedial and valid retrospectively as per legislative practice and British precedents

anchor.surface_text: Our brother Sikri has cited an instance of the British Parliament... settled legislative practice to make validation laws... Parliament and Legislatures can make laws operate retrospectively

arguments.court_reasoning: Not directly engaged; Parliament can regulate via 191(1)(e)

arguments.claim: Government created special office alternatively to briefing lawyer; chose to create office

anchor.surface_text: When the Government of Rajasthan appointed Mrs. Kathuria it had two courses open to it. Firstly, Government could have engaged Mrs. Kathuria to conduct the particular arbitration case

arguments.claim: Rowlatt J definition approved in Statesman, McMillan, Mahadeo; applies here no office

anchor.surface_text: This definition was approved by Lord Atkinson... Lord Atkin... Lord Wright... In Mahadeo v. Shantibhai Ors... quoted with approval the definition of Lord Wright.

arguments.claim: High Court held Mrs. Kathuria disqualified under Art 191

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the High Court held that Mrs. Kathuria was disqualified.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: at both the numberle and learned Lords had accepted the language employed by Rowlatt J. as generally sufficient. In Mahadeos case 1 , this Court was d

holdings.text: Mrs. Kanta Kathuria was holding an office of profit under the Government of Rajasthan as Special Government Pleader, disqualifying her under Article 191(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, hold that the High Court was right in its conclusion that Mrs.,Kathuria held an office. Since there is no dispute that it was for profit and under the State, the election of Mrs. Kathuria must be held to be void as she was disqualified to stand for the election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Rowlatt J. test: subsisting permanent substantive position independent of holder, previously held by another, satisfying all tests.

holdings.text: The office of profit disqualification stood removed by the retrospective operation of the Rajasthan Act.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that while we hold that Mrs. Kathuria held an office of profit under the State Government, we hold further that this disqualification stood removed by the retrospective operation of the Act under discussion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature competent under Art 191(1)(a) to declare retrospectively; no constitutional prohibition; settled legislative practice including British precedents.

holdings.text: The election petition was not bad for non-joinder of Shri Mathura Das Mathur under section 82 RPA as he was candidate from another constituency.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.82(b) refers to 'any other candidate' meaning at the same election/constituency.

holdings.text: Mrs. Kanta Kathuria was not holding an office of profit under Article 191(1)(a) as Special Government Pleader.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment under CPC Order 27 R8(b) and S2(7) is mere engagement to assist, not creating independent subsisting permanent office per Rowlatt J. test; no office exists apart from holder.

holdings.text: Rajasthan Act No.5 of 1969 validly removes the disqualification retrospectively even if office of profit existed.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above reasons We are of the opinion that the impugned Act is valid and removes the disqualification if it existed before.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State legislature competent to legislate retrospectively under Art 191(1)(a); no express/implied bar; follows judicial precedents on retrospective laws.

holdings.text: The impugned Act does not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: No material has been placed to show that any such offices exist. We cannot, therefore, entertain this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of analogous Central Government offices to show discrimination.

holdings.text: Election petition not defective for non-joinder under S.82 RPA.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.82(b) 'any other candidate' limited to same constituency election.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1832 of 1967-Mahadeo Shantibhai , Others-s-decided on October 15, 1968 , we held that a panel lawyer engaged to watch cases on behalf of the Central Western Railway Administrations, held an office of profit.

precedents.cited_proposition: panel lawyer engaged to watch cases on behalf of railway held an office of profit
precedents.cited_holding: panel lawyer held an office of profit

precedents.citation: Statesman P Ltd. v. H. R. Deb Ors 1

anchor.surface_text: Statesman P Ltd. v. H. R. Deb Ors 1  In the Statesman case, this Court approved of the observations of Lord Wright in Mcmillan v. Guest 2  to the following effect The word office is of indefinite companytent.

precedents.case_name: Statesman Pvt Ltd v H R Deb

anchor.surface_text: McMillan v. Guest 2  to the following effect The word office is of indefinite companytent. Its various meanings companyer four companyumns of the New English  1  1968 3 S.C.R. 614.  2  1942 A.C. 561. Dictionary, but I take as the most relevant for purpose of this case the following A position or place to which certain duties are attached, especially one of a more or less public character.

precedents.cited_proposition: definition of 'office' as a position or place to which certain duties are attached especially of public character

precedents.citation: Great Western Railway Co. v. Baler 1

anchor.surface_text: Great Western Railway Co. v. Baler 1 . Justice Rowlatt said thus Now it is argued, and to my mind argued most forcibly, that shows that what those who use the language of the Act of 1842 meant, when they spoke of an office or employment which was a subsisting permanent, substantive position, which had an existence independent from the person who filled it, which went on and was filled in succession by successive holders, and if you merely had any man who was engaged on whatever terms, to do duties which were assigned to him, his employmen t to do those duties did number create an office to which those duties were attached.

precedents.case_name: Great Western Railway Co v Bater
precedents.cited_proposition: office means subsisting permanent substantive position independent of holder filled successively

precedents.citation: Great Western Railway Company v. Bater l 1 8 Tax Cases 231.

anchor.surface_text: Great Western Railway Company v. Bater l 1 8 Tax Cases 231. language of the Act of 1842 meant, when they spoke of an office or an employment, was an office or employment which was a subsisting, permanent, substantive position, which had an existence independent from the person who filled it which went on and was filled in succession by successive holders and if you merely had a man who was engaged on whatever terms, to do duties which were assigned to him, his employment to do those duties did number create an office to which those duties were attached.

precedents.case_name: Great Western Railway Company v Bater
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of office by Rowlatt J
precedents.cited_holding: office is subsisting permanent substantive position independent from the person who filled it

precedents.citation: McMillan v. Guest  H.M. Inspector of Taxes   1

anchor.surface_text: McMillan v. Guest  H.M. Inspector of Taxes   1 . Lord Atkin observed at page 201 - There is numberstatutory definition of office. Without adopting the sentence as a companyplete definition, one may treat the following expression of Rowlatt, J., in Great Western Railway Co. v. Baler, 1920 3 K.B., at page 274, adopted by Lord Atkinson in that case, 1922 2 A.C., at page 15, as a generally sufficient statement of the meaning of the word an office or employment which was a subsisting, permanent, substantive position, which had an existence independent of the person who filed it, which went on and was filled in succession by successive holders.

precedents.cited_proposition: acceptance of Rowlatt J's definition of office

precedents.citation: Great Western Railway Co. v. Baler, 1920 3 K.B., at page 274

anchor.surface_text: Great Western Railway Co. v. precedents.case_name: Great Western Railway Co v Baler
precedents.cited_proposition: Rowlatt J's expression on meaning of office

Clause  13  of the terms in that case read as follows - You will be expected to watch cases companying up for hearing against this Railway in the various companyrts at UJB and give timely intimation of the same to this office.

precedents.citation: Sakhawat Ali v. The State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: Sakhawat Ali v. The State of Orissa 1  provides an instance where the Legislature provided that a paid legal practitioner should number stand in the municipal elections.

precedents.cited_proposition: legislature can disqualify paid legal practitioner from standing in elections

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, hold that the High Court was right in its conclusion that Mrs.,Kathuria held an office. Since there is no dispute that it was for profit and under the State, the election of Mrs. Kathuria must be held to be void as she was disqualified to stand for the election.

The result, therefore, is that while we hold that Mrs. Kathuria held an office of profit under the State Government, we hold further that this disqualification stood removed by the retrospective operation of the Act under discussion.
In the result the appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the petition dismissed. In the circumstances of the case the parties will bear their own costs throughout.
